title: Low Pressure Headache / Spontaneous Intracranial Hypotension
icd10: G97.0 (Cerebrospinal fluid leak from spinal puncture)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of headache due to low cerebrospinal fluid pressure in adults. Covers spontaneous intracranial hypotension (SIH), post-lumbar puncture headache (PDPH), and post-surgical/post-traumatic CSF leaks. Includes diagnostic workup (MRI brain, MRI spine, CT myelography, cisternography), conservative management, epidural blood patch, and surgical repair for refractory cases. Excludes cranial CSF rhinorrhea/otorrhea from skull base defects (managed by otolaryngology/neurosurgery), and CSF leaks secondary to VP shunt overdrainage.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out infection or anemia contributing to symptoms
Electrolytes, renal function; baseline before IV fluids and medications
Required before epidural blood patch or lumbar puncture; assess bleeding risk
Rule out inflammatory or infectious cause of meningeal enhancement
Affects imaging decisions (gadolinium, CT myelography) and treatment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypothyroidism can cause headache; rule out secondary cause
Low magnesium can worsen headache; contributes to muscle cramps
If febrile or concern for meningitis/epidural abscess mimicking SIH
Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos screening; associated with dural weakness

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for connective tissue disorders
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Recurrent SIH in young patients; EDS, Marfan syndrome evaluation
Confirm CSF vs. other fluid if rhinorrhea or otorrhea present
Localize CSF leak site when MRI and CT myelography are inconclusive

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Diagnostic criterion for intracranial hypotension; <6 cm H2O diagnostic but may be normal (0-6 cm H2O supports diagnosis)
Lumbar Puncture.target: <6 cm H2O (may be 0 or negative; normal in 20-30%)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out meningitis or SAH; SIH may show mild pleocytosis (<5-50 WBC)
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC <5 typical; mild elevation possible in SIH

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Often mildly elevated in SIH (45-100 mg/dL) due to meningeal irritation; rule out infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal 15-45 mg/dL; mildly elevated in SIH is expected

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out bacterial meningitis if fever or meningismus present
Rule out traumatic tap vs. xanthochromia from chronic SIH-related subdural collections
Lumbar Puncture.target: Document; xanthochromia may occur in SIH

Essential/First-line.timing: First-line diagnostic study; perform urgently if SIH suspected
Essential/First-line.target: Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagging, subdural collections, pituitary engorgement, venous distension sign

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation and management of intracranial hypotension
Anesthesiology or pain medicine consult for epidural blood patch placement
Neuroradiology consult for CT myelography interpretation and leak localization
Interventional radiology consult for CT-guided fibrin glue injection or targeted epidural blood patch
Neurosurgery consult for surgical dural repair if refractory to blood patch and fibrin glue treatments
Neurosurgery consult for subdural hematoma evaluation if symptomatic mass effect develops
Headache specialist referral for chronic post-SIH headache or persistent symptoms despite leak resolution
Genetics/rheumatology referral for connective tissue disorder evaluation if recurrent spontaneous CSF leaks
Physical therapy for gradual return to activity and deconditioning after prolonged bed rest

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Remain flat or in Trendelenburg position as much as possible to reduce headache while awaiting definitive treatment (upright posture worsens symptoms)
Increase oral fluid intake to at least 2-3 liters daily to support CSF production and hydration
Increase caffeine intake (coffee, tea) to 300-500 mg/day as this constricts cerebral blood vessels and may reduce headache
Avoid Valsalva maneuvers (straining, heavy lifting, coughing) which can worsen or re-open CSF leaks
After epidural blood patch: lie flat for 1-2 hours post-procedure, then gradually increase activity over 24-48 hours; avoid heavy lifting for 2-4 weeks

Return to ED immediately if headache suddenly becomes the worst headache of life, new neurologic symptoms develop (weakness, numbness, vision changes, confusion), or fever occurs (may indicate subdural hematoma, meningitis, or abscess)
Some patients have persistent headache after successful leak treatment; this typically improves over weeks to months
Follow up with neurology in 1-2 weeks after epidural blood patch to assess response and plan further workup if needed

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stay well-hydrated (2-3 L daily) to support CSF production and overall recovery
Gradual return to physical activity after symptom resolution; avoid strenuous exercise for 4-6 weeks after blood patch
Avoid excessive caffeine withdrawal if caffeine has been used therapeutically (taper gradually to prevent rebound headache)
Compression stockings during prolonged bed rest for DVT prevention; ambulate when tolerated
If connective tissue disorder identified: avoid contact sports and activities with high risk of spinal trauma
Inform future anesthesiologists of SIH history; use smallest gauge spinal needle if LP/spinal anesthesia required in future

differential.tests: Clinical history; no pachymeningeal enhancement on MRI; no orthostatic pattern

differential.tests: History of procedure; timing correlation; response to blood patch

differential.tests: LP with elevated OP; MRI shows empty sella, optic nerve sheath distension (no pachymeningeal enhancement)

differential.features: Progressive headache; seizures; focal deficits; hypercoagulable state; papilledema
differential.tests: MRV or CT venography showing venous thrombosis

differential.features: Fever, neck stiffness, photophobia; meningeal enhancement may mimic SIH
differential.tests: CSF pleocytosis, low glucose, positive cultures; fever; systemic illness

differential.features: Nodular (not smooth) meningeal enhancement; cranial neuropathies; known malignancy
differential.tests: MRI shows nodular enhancement (vs. smooth in SIH); CSF cytology positive

differential.features: Positional headache may overlap; but usually Valsalva-provoked; not clearly orthostatic
differential.tests: MRI sagittal showing tonsillar descent >5 mm below foramen magnum; no pachymeningeal enhancement

differential.features: Positional headache (worse with certain head positions); intermittent hydrocephalus
differential.tests: MRI/CT showing colloid cyst in third ventricle; acute hydrocephalus

differential.features: Headache, confusion, focal deficits; history of trauma or anticoagulation
differential.tests: CT/MRI showing subdural collection without brain sagging or pachymeningeal enhancement

differential.features: Chronic daily headache; overuse of analgesics >15 days/month
differential.tests: Medication diary; no orthostatic pattern; no MRI enhancement

differential.features: Orthostatic symptoms (lightheadedness, palpitations); headache may be positional
differential.tests: Tilt table test; HR increase >30 bpm without significant BP drop; normal MRI brain

differential.features: Bilateral, pressing, mild-moderate; no positional component

disposition.criteria: Mild orthostatic headache responsive to oral analgesics and caffeine; able to tolerate PO; no red flags (new neurologic deficits, fever, worst headache of life); outpatient MRI and neurology follow-up within 1 week arranged

Severe orthostatic headache preventing ambulation or oral intake; need for IV hydration and caffeine; scheduled for epidural blood patch; new diagnosis of SIH requiring urgent MRI and workup; concern for subdural hematoma
Post-dural puncture headache not responding to conservative measures after 24-48 hours; awaiting epidural blood patch
Large subdural hematoma with mass effect or neurologic deterioration; posterior fossa crowding from brain sagging with signs of brainstem compression
Headache significantly improved (>50% reduction) after EBP or conservative treatment; tolerating oral medications; able to ambulate; close outpatient follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
Mild symptoms manageable with oral analgesics and caffeine; able to maintain hydration; no red flags; MRI brain already obtained or scheduled; neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks
Post-EBP: 1-2 weeks; Refractory SIH: weekly until improved; After resolution: 3 months then annually for 1-2 years to monitor for recurrence
